[h1]Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Origins was controversial for swapping classic AC systems for a full RPG, but for me the switch works. Egypt looks stunning, exploration is rewarding, and the loot, levels, and abilities fit the fantasy better than I expected. It is not perfect and the activity loop can get repetitive, but as an RPG take on AC this is probably the best in the series.

[hr]
[h1]Story Overview[/h1]
You play Bayek of Siwa, a Medjay who travels Ptolemaic Egypt hunting those responsible for a personal tragedy. Alongside Aya, you uncover a wider conspiracy involving powerful figures across the Nile. Your choices and discoveries lead toward the beginnings of what will become the Assassin Brotherhood.

[hr]
[h1]World and Atmosphere[/h1]
Ancient Egypt is a delight to explore. From the Nile delta and Faiyum to Gizaâ€™s pyramids and desert dunes, the world feels huge, detailed, and believable. Sandstorms, starry nights, and sun baked villages sell the mood. Tombs, ruins, and hidden chambers make free roaming feel like real discovery.

[hr]
[h1]Combat and RPG Systems[/h1]
This is where the shift lands. Weapons have levels and rarity, enemies have levels, and you build a skill tree across Hunter, Warrior, and Seer. Melee feels weighty, bows have clear roles, and tools like smoke bombs, fire, and poison keep fights interesting. It is easy to grasp but deep enough to tune a playstyle you enjoy.

[hr]
[h1]Exploration and Activities[/h1]
Tombs with light puzzles, papyrus riddles, stone circles, war elephants, and plenty of camps to infiltrate. Senu the eagle replaces old Eagle Vision and makes scouting feel natural. The map is huge and generally rewarding, though clearing every outpost for achievements can start to blur together.

[hr]
[h1]Progression and Gear[/h1]
Lots of loot and crafting. Hunting for materials upgrades quiver, bracers, pouch, and breastplate. Dismantling gear is useful, and late game legendaries change how you approach fights. The tree is generous and lets you unlock what fits your flow rather than forcing one path.

[hr]
[h1]Characters and Performances[/h1]
Bayek is easily one of the strongest AC protagonists, with grounded motives and a believable arc. Ayaâ€™s segments add momentum and perspective. Voice acting is solid across allies and villains.

[hr]
[h1]What Works[/h1]
[list]
[*] Beautiful, massive Egypt that invites real exploration
[*] RPG combat and abilities that fit the fantasy
[*] Senu scouting, tombs, and puzzle side content
[*] Bayek as a standout lead with strong voice work
[*] Rewards for curiosity through riddles and secrets
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]What Falls Short[/h1]
[list]
[*] Activity loop can feel repetitive when sweeping every region
[*] First time RPG systems can be overwhelming if you come straight from older ACs
[*] Some UI and inventory clutter while juggling lots of loot
[/list]

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Big thumbs up. If you can accept the RPG pivot, Origins delivers a gorgeous world, satisfying combat, and a great lead character. It is the AC I recommend when someone wants the series at open world scale with modern systems, even if the checklist grind shows up during 100 percent runs.

Bayek of Siwa is a triumph of writing however. His story traces a deeply emotional journey from vengeance to conviction. First of all, i like Bayek as an assasin, but the story is hella boring and there are alot of negative things that i dont like such as:

Anyway the DLC was pretty good, i liked the story and bosses, the base game is just boring.
